Let $N\geq 1$ and let $t(N)$ be the least integer $t$ such that there is no solution to\[1=\frac{1}{n_1}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n_k}\]with $t=n_1<\cdots <n_k\leq N$. Estimate $t(N)$.



Erd\H{o}s and Graham \cite{ErGr80} could show\[t(N)\ll\frac{N}{\log N},\]but had no idea of the true value of $t(N)$.

Solved by Liu and Sawhney \cite{LiSa24} (up to $(\log\log N)^{O(1)}$), who proved that\[\frac{N}{(\log N)(\log\log N)^3(\log\log\log N)^{O(1)}}\ll t(N) \ll \frac{N}{\log N}.\]




References


[ErGr80] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Graham, R., Old and new problems and results in combinatorial number theory. Monographies de L'Enseignement Mathematique (1980).

[LiSa24] Liu, Y. and Sawhney, M., On further questions regarding unit fractions. arXiv:2404.07113 (2024).
